elements.value: What is Web Development?
Understanding the Fundamentals

Web development is the process of creating websites and web applications for the internet or intranet. It encompasses a range of tasks, including web design, web content development, client-side/server-side scripting, and network security configuration. Web developers use various programming languages and frameworks to build dynamic and interactive user experiences.
/web-development-intro.jpg

In this chapter, we will discuss the various components of web development, including front-end and back-end development, and the technologies that power the web. By the end of this chapter, you will have a solid understanding of what web development entails and the skills required to become a successful web developer.

Creating Engaging User Interfaces
HTML, CSS, and JavaScript

Front-end development focuses on the client side of web applications, which is everything that users see and interact with in their web browsers. The core technologies used in front-end development are HTML (HyperText Markup Language), CSS (Cascading Style Sheets), and JavaScript. HTML structures the content, CSS styles it, and JavaScript adds interactivity. Together, these technologies create a seamless user experience.
/frontend-development.jpg

In this chapter, we will delve deeper into each of these technologies. You will learn how to create responsive layouts with CSS, enhance user interactions with JavaScript, and utilize frameworks such as React or Vue.js to build modern web applications. By the end of this chapter, you will be equipped with the foundational skills to create visually appealing and functional web pages.
Building the Server-Side Logic
Server, Database, and APIs

Back-end development involves server-side logic and database interactions that power web applications. It is responsible for managing user connections, storing and retrieving data, and ensuring that everything on the front end works seamlessly. Back-end developers typically work with server-side languages such as Node.js, Python, Ruby, or PHP, and they often use databases like MySQL, PostgreSQL, or MongoDB to manage data.
